and phase II, which aims to upgrade about 13,300 kilometers (km)

Project will be the fifth in the series of interventions, supporting the 
last stage of the institutional strengthening program and financing 
the upgrading of the north-south corridor. A road safety zone will 
be implemented, and awareness on the risks of HIV/AIDS (human

Although  road  density  in  India  is  higher  than  that  in  many 
developing countries, road network standards and conditions are 
inadequate  to  meet  rapidly  growing  freight  and  passenger  traffic. 
Only  6%  of  national  highways  (NHs)  have  four  or  more  lanes, 
about  25%  of  NHs  have  poor  surface  conditions,  and  many are 
seriously congested. This situation raises road-user costs; impairs 
road  safety  and  the  quality  and  frequency  of  transport  services; 
and  limits  roads’  contribution  to  national  development,  economic 
growth, and poverty reduction.  
 
Faced with the NH  system’s  capacity  shortage,  the  Government 
has  initiated  several  radical  actions,  including  (i)  launching  the 
ambitious NHDP, (ii) establishing the National Highways Authority 
of  India  (NHAI),  (iii)  creating  a  central  road  fund,  and  (iv) 
promoting PSP.

Faced  with  the  highway  system’s  capacity  shortage,  the  Government  has  initiated 
several  actions,  including  (i)  launching  ambitious  NH  programs;  (ii)  establishing  the  National

9. 
National  Highways  Development  Program.  In  1998,  the  Government  launched  the 
National  Highways  Development  Program  (NHDP)  to  rehabilitate  and  widen  the  golden 
quadrilateral  (about  6,000  km),  connecting  the  major  cities  of  Delhi,  Mumbai,  Kolkata,  and 
Chennai. This program has been substantially completed. The second phase of NHDP (NHDP-
II) consisting of upgrading the north-south corridor (about 4,000 km) and the east-west corridor 
(about 3,300 km) is currently under implementation and expected to be completed by December 
2007. The third phase of NHDP (NHDP-III) is currently under consideration by the Government, 
covering  about  10,000  km,  and  consisting  of  (i)  corridors  of  high-density  traffic;  (ii)  corridors 
linking  state  capitals  to  the  NHDP  network;  and  (iii)  roads  providing  access  to  tourist  and 
economic centers.3 
 
10. 
Separation between Policy and Implementation Functions. The Ministry of Shipping, 
Road  Transport  and  Highways  (MSRTH)  is  responsible  for  developing  and  maintaining  NHs; 
formulating road transport policies; coordinating state roads; and issuing guidelines on highway 
planning, design, and construction. In 1988, to separate MSRTH’s planning and implementation 
functions, NHAI was established as a statutory body.  Initially,  it was given the responsibility for 
building and maintaining the NH network and expressways under externally aided projects and 
PSP. In 1998, NHAI became responsible for implementing the NHDP.  
 
11. 
Road  Financing.  To  develop  the  road  network,  a  dedicated  central  road  fund  was 
established, mainly supported by an additional excise duty (“cess”) on petrol and diesel, which 
initially was Rs1.0 per liter, and increased to Rs1.5 in 2003. About one third of the funds are for 
NHs  and  have  been  committed  until  2018  to  implement  the  NHDP-I,  NHDP-II, and service its 
debt.  To  complete  the  NHDP-I  and  NHDP-II,  NHAI  estimated  that  a  total  of  $33.8  billion  over 
FY1999-2019  is  required:  $15.1  billion  for  capital  financing  and  $18.7  billion  for  debt  service. 
NHAI  is  expected  to  raise  $17.7  billion  from  cess,  $10.7  from  market  borrowings,  $3.6  billion 
from external assistance, and $1.8 billion from private sector financing. The proposed NHDP-III 
is intended to be implemented under PSP schemes to the largest extent possible.

Project  Implementation  Capacity.  About  3,970  km  of  NHDP  network  have  been 
completed, 400 km will be completed by December 2004, and about 2,600 km will be completed 
by  December  2006.  More  than  6,000  km  of  NHDP-II  have  yet  to  be  awarded.  The  average 
contract implementation period is 2.5–3.0 years. To complete the NHDP-II by the end of 2007 
as planned, all remaining works have to be awarded by the first semester of 2005. So far, NHAI 
has issued about 35 contracts for a total of 1,400 km per year on average. To meet the target 
completion date, NHAI needs to improve its capacity to prepare and contract out projects. While 
keeping  the  organization  lean  is  important,  the  magnitude  of  the  remaining  tasks  will  require 
NHAI to revisit its human resources capacity. Managing a large number of consultants engaged 
for  project  preparation  is  difficult,  sometimes  leading  to  poor-quality  outputs  due  to  lack  of 
supervision  and  quality  control.  NHAI  has  thus  established  a  technical  review  function 
mechanism,  by  involving  experts  from  outside  NHAI,  for  quality  control.  The  technical  review 
team’s  role  is  to  review  all  feasibility  reports  and  detailed  project  designs  prepared by NHAI 
consultants. The final approval is provided by a technical audit team, consisting of chief general 
managers; and technical, finance, and environment and social general managers (GMs).   
 
14. 
NHAI  outsources  construction  supervision  to  private  consulting  firms.  Management 
oversight  is  provided  through  project  implementation  units  (PIUs)  run  by  NHAI  senior  staff. 
Engineers’ high level of authority, together with the internal audit system, ensures efficient and 
objective decision-making. Although this has enabled NHAI to improve project implementation, 
as of March 2004, of 78 projects under implementation, 31 were reportedly 2–12 months late.  
 
15. 
NHAI  also  recognizes  that,  while  it  needs  to  strengthen  its  contract  management  and 
supervision  capacity,  it  also  needs  to  improve  highway  standards  and  the  code  of  practice. 
Planning,  design,  construction,  and  operation  of  roads  are  generally  based  on  standards  and 
codes  of  practice  prepared  and  published  by  the  Indian  Roads  Congress.  For  specific 
application to NH works, MSRTH and/or NHAI also issue instructions and guidelines from time 
to time. However, some of the standards require updating and rationalization to be compatible 
with the ground situation and international practice. While the regulatory function remains with 
MSRTH, with its experience in developing over 6,000 km of highways, NHAI can better provide 
input to improve highway standards and the code of practice.  
 
16.

Resettlement Principles and Compensation  

B. 
 
9. 
The resettlement plan is based on the resettlement and rehabilitation framework adopted 
by  the  National  Highways  Authority  of  India  (NHAI)  for  ADB-funded  projects,  complying  with 
ADB  guidelines.  The  plan  aims  to  adequately  compensate  all  types  of  losses  and  impacts 
resulting  from  the  Project,  and  to  restore  and  improve  the  economic condition of the affected 
population.  The  entitlement  policy  recognizes  all  types  of  affected  people,  including  squatters, 
vulnerable  encroachers,  titleholders,  and  kiosk  owners.  All  squatters,  vulnerable  encroachers, 
and  kiosk  owners  present  before  the  cut-off  date  will  be  entitled  to  assistance.  Barring  kiosk 
owners,  others  will  be  paid  the  replacement  cost  for  structures,  and  shifting  and  transition 
allowances. Kiosk owners will receive a lump sum as a shifting allowance. Training will be given

receive  shifting  allowances,  rental  allowance,  deposits,  and  compensation  for  erected 
structures,  if  any.  Material  can  be  salvaged  at  no  cost.  All  incidental  costs—registration cost, 
stamp  duty,  etc.—will  be  borne  by  the  Project.  It  will  rebuild  community  utilities  and 
infrastructure that are to be dismantled. The policy also asserts an integrated income restoration

time  economic  rehabilitation  grant  to  establish  their  businesses  and  livelihood.  All  common 
property resources will be replaced before demolition of the old ones. Specific entitlements for 
the  different  categories  of  losses  are  contained  in  the  entitlement  matrix  (Supplementary 
Appendix J).

11. 
All  efforts  will  be  made  to  settle  affected  people’s  grievances  as  amicably  as  possible. 
Out-of-court  settlement  is  preferred  since  this  expedites  dispute  settlement  and  helps  timely 
project implementation. Grievance redress committees (GRCs) will be set up at the district level, 
comprising  representatives  of  local  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs);  public  agencies 
representatives; women’s groups, squatters, and vulnerable affected peoples; line departments 
and  affected  people,  especially  women;  and  a  representative  of  the  respective  district 
administrations. At least two people from each group will be in the GRC. Women will make up at 
least  a  third  of  GRC  members.  Investigations  will  be  thorough  enough  to  satisfy  affected 
peoples. The GRC will meet quarterly or more frequently as required and respond a grievance 
in 15 days. It will continue to function during the entire life of the Project, including the defects 
liability  periods,  to  (i)  help  affected  peoples  solve  problems  arising  out  of  land  and  property 
acquisition; (ii) record the grievances, and categorize, prioritize, and solve them within a month; 
(iii)  inform  PIUs  of  serious  cases  within  an  appropriate  time  frame;  and  (iv)  report  to  the 
aggrieved parties about progress on their grievances and the PIUs’ decisions. 

Relocation Site Development and Rehabilitation Assistance 

D. 
 
12. 
Requirements for relocating affected people will be known only after the census surveys 
are  completed.  The  final  RP  will  include  more  details  on  this.  Displaced  titleholders  and 
squatters losing residential and commercial properties may opt for resettlement sites, preferably 
close to where they lived before the Project. The RP provides residential plots of all squatters, 
who may choose self-relocation with compensation and related assistance. PIUs and NGOs will 
determine  if  each  household  can  find  replacement  land  for  a  dwelling,  and,  if  the  household

Implementation Framework and Budget 

E. 
 
13. 
NHAI’s environment and social development unit (ESDU) will coordinate and supervise 
resettlement. Resettlement  and  rehabilitation  cells  will  be  established  under  PIUs.  Each  PIU, 
headed  by  a  project  director  or  a  project  manager,  will  be  supported  by  a  manager  for 
resettlement and environmental issues. Experienced NGOs (one per package) will be engaged 
to  implement  resettlement  activities  and  coordinate  with  other  relevant  departments  and 
stakeholders  in  the  Project.  The  NGOs  will  also  organize  and  conduct  training  programs, 
conduct  awareness  campaigns,  verify  affected  peoples  and  their  assets,  and  help  settle 
disputes.  At  the  district  level  GRCs  will  help  the  PIU  resolve  disputes  and  implement  the 
resettlement plan. Additional staff for resettlement will be provided as necessary to improve the 
ESDU’s capacity.  

Resettlement  will  take  40  months,  including  planning,  surveying,  assessing,  policy 
15. 
development,  institution  identification,  affected  people’s  participation,  income  restoration,  and 
other  resettlement  activities.  For  each  section,  compensation  for  acquired  assets  will  be  paid 
before construction begins, and resettlement sites built before people are relocated. 

16. 
The  resettlement  budget  of  Rs.360  million  covers  (i)  compensation  (62.7%),  (ii) 
supplementary assistance (21.0%), (iii) replacement of common property resources (6.0%), (iv) 
resettlement implementation support (6.8%), and (v) contingencies (3.5%).  

Monitoring and Evaluation 

F. 
 
Internal  and  external  monitoring  will  be  in  place  as  specified  in  the  resettlement  plan. 
17. 
The  PIU  will  carry  out  internal  monitoring,  while  an  external  monitoring  agency  (EMA)  will 
conduct  third-party  monitoring  and  midterm  and  end-term  evaluation.  The  EMA  will  submit 
periodic  progress  reports  to  NHAI,  which  will  then  submit  them  to  ADB  in  the  first  year  of 
monitoring, after which the EMA will submit quarterly reports. The EMA will carry out a midterm 
evaluation  based  on  a  25%  sample  of  affected  peoples,  covering  titleholders  and  non-
titleholders, at the end of eighteenth month of the contract. At the end of the third year, end-line 
evaluation  will  be  carried  out.  Monitoring  and  evaluation  formats  are  given  in the resettlement 
plan.
